titleStmt.title: Letter to Mary Behrend, typed and sent by Irvin Kochel

fileDesc.extent: Standar size piece of onion paper from 1955, printed front and back, single sheet.

seriesStmt.p: Letter from a series of letters between Mary Behrend and Irvin Kochel.

notesStmt.note: Irvin Kochel was the Administrative Head for Penn State Behrend (Previously known as the Behrend Center). He coresponded with Mary Behrend, who was the owner of the land Penn State Behrend was built on.

sourceDesc.p: Thin piece of onion paper typed with a type writer, front and back. Left side of the paper is crumpled a bit. Text can be seen through the page.

body.p: Dear Mrs. Behrend: In reference to your recent letters, I offer the following comments-- We would be most pleased to have Mr. Paul Laver from the Cemetery do certain planting around the entrance to the Behrend Center campus. We understand that this planting will be done by utilizing the existing shrubery in the formal gardens. It is also my understanding that you will reimburse Mr. Laven for his labors only for the planting around the entrance and for no other plant- ing. If you have not already done so, I would suggest that you contact Mr. Day infomring him of your desures to have Mr. Laver do the above mentioned work.

Insofar as the new building is concerned, we do not plant to proceed with this project this year. We have not as yet heard from General Electric as to their intention of us doing their training program this fall. It will be impossible at this late date to complete any building arrangments for the Fall term, con- sequently we have delayed any action on a new building for this present year. We do, however, plan to spend approcimately $25,000.00 completing the other half of the barn for utilisation as classrooms.

We have located some of the lights for the living room which are in need of repair. At the present time we will investigate the repair of these lights and I will re- port to you at a later date as to whether or not they can be effectively repaired.

We are making arrangments to erect a wrough iron rail around the case in which the Niagra is displayed. Quite a few people have commented about the ship and have visited us with the express purpose of viewing it. Under separate cover we are sending you the television films of the presentation of the Flagship. These films can be shown on a standard 16mm. projector.

In refrence to the heating of the swimming pool, I have talked on two different occasions with Mr. Scobell about completing the project. As yet he has done nothing to heat the pool with the exception of having ordered a piece of equip- ment that is needed to put the furnace in operating order. You might write Mr. Scobell asking him what progress he is making on this project.This may timu- late him to do something in the immediate future to complete it.

In reference to the scholarships, as a result of our last Advisory Board meeting, Mr. Nick appointed a new Scholarship Committee, consisting of Jerry Stokes, Chair- man, William Hamilton and John Zurn. I have had one meeting with Mr. Stokes and we are planning to arrange for a number of scholarships which will be available
-2- by September 1956. Our scholarship fund at present has been consumed so that there is only $650.00 remaining in this fund. We havegiven one scholarship to a McDowell High School student for September 1955. The scholarship fund has not been generally advertised this year because of the small amount of money available. We have not in the past had scholarships that were specifically designated as Protestant scholarships. Inasmuch as we are a state university we do not feel that it would be ethical to differentiate as to religion or race in the issuance of scholarship. I will keep you informed of the activities of this committee and what programs they make. I am quite sure that we will be building the scholarship fund to the point where at least one scholarship will be available to all eleven of the area high school each year. Generally speak- ing scholarships are in the amount of $100.00 per year, per student.

Ross P. Wright of Reed Mfg. Company has sent us several copies of letters that were supposedly writted by Commodore Perry on the deck of the Ship Niagra on the afternoon of his victory. We plan to have these copies framed and placed in Erie Hall along with the Flagship. I hope this letter finds you in good health and enjoying the summer. Please give my kindest regards to Gail. Our family is well and in good health.
Cordially yours, Irvin H. Kochel Administrative Head
P.S. Thanks very much for the London Illustrated News. We will put these to good use in the Library at Behrend Center.
